Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2011 05:17AM dianaleo wrote: I have just recovered from my third bout of shingles in my right eye.  It sure takes your mind off cancer!  I am going to get the vaccine this week, although I guess it is not as effective as other vaccines.  Onc and Ophathamologist do not know if it will work for me.  I couldn't get it while I had the outbreak.  The first time I had it, it was really bad and very painful.  Now I know when it is starting and get the anti-viral medicine before it gets too bad.  They are most effective if you get the anti-virals within 72 hrs. of outbreak. I think my immune system is shot to hell as I am testing positive with high ANA test for an autoimmune reaction although they have eliminated several diseases, they still do not know what is causing it.  I have been suffering with excruciating pain in my wrists which sent me running to rheumatologist who did all the testing.  All I do is go to doctors - it gets discouraging.  That said, hang in there, Jenn, the medicines do  help.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 03:30PM dianaleo wrote: Hi McBird - Welcome to this site. Although no one wants to be here, there is a lot of information and support here.  When I was first diagnosed with BC stage III in 1996 I did not drink diet anything.  I became stage IV in 2009 and probably drank 1-2 diet cokes a day.  I mentioned it to my onc, but he didn't seem concerned at all.  Did not tell me to stop.  I think we all look to what might have contributed to our BC but perhaps none of it matters.  I never smoked, drank very much, was not overweight, have never had much food with preservatives, no family history, had regular mammograms and here I am - stage IV.  I cannot think how I could have prevented this.  I had a friend who was diabetic and drank excessive amounts of diet drinks - almost like a chain smoker - never had BC - but did succumb to heart disease from the diabetes.  Of course the best thing to do is speak to your onc about it.  I thought perhaps stress had brought mine back, but my onc just said it could be, but no one knows at this point and everyone has stress in their lives - kids, finances, spouses, jobs, etc.  Let us know what your onc thinks.

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 11:38AM dianaleo wrote: Dear LJmom.  I am having one of those days also.  I am just mad at the world and I don't want anyone to cheer me up.  I'll get over it sooner or later.  I have a mother-in-law that calls every night to ask "how are you feeling-are you a little better?" and that's driving me insane and of course if she didn't call I'd probably be mad.  I'm not sure anyone can win with me.  I can do most things myself still, but everyone just seems to expect it.  I don't think my grown-up children are particularly concerned about my health as they still see me doing everything and make-up helps cover up my ashy-looking skin.  I am probably my own worst enemy - in denial one minute and resentful the next.  My husband is going through his own battle with kidney cancer and doesn't have a very good prognosis, so he does know exactly what I am feeling, but right now he is feeling good and it's hard for him to deal with me not feeling good and not wanting to do stuff. Generally, I take a pain pill and keep going, but this whole thing sucks - there are days when I have a very hard time getting out of bed and facing the day.  I am on anti-depressant, but I guess it can only help so much.  There, I haven't been of help or comfort to anyone, but it felt good putting it down on paper.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 02:01PM dianaleo wrote: For the most part I don't have a problem talking to people about it or just saying I'm doing pretty good and try to change the subject.  I don't think they really want to hear all the ins and outs of this thing.  The one, however, that drives me insane is my 96 year old mother-in-law who really does care, but every evening she calls to find out how I am.  She always says "but you feel a little better, right?"   I've tried saying it won't get better, but I'm doing alright - she refuses to hear it.  Then she tells me all about her 95 year old friends and their ailments and how bad off they are.  The one that really gets to me is when she says "just tell me you're a little better and then I'll feel better."  I know she cares very much, but this conversation once a week would be more than enough.  Her mind is perfectly intact and she is a very bright woman so age is not an excuse.  She has always been so kind and good to me that I feel I must just keep getting through the phone call every night.  I guess I should appreciate that she is sincere in her concern.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2012 11:26PM dianaleo wrote:  Thanks for your responses - I have been feeling very alone in this battle.  I have been on antihormonals since my dx in 2009, but this week I must start xeloda as my tumor markers have continued to rise on every drug, plus my scans show some progression of bone mets.  I am pretty familiar with the joint pain of those drugs, but this is totally different. I have been having this since about July, but neither oncologists suggested this dx.  The rheumatologist was able to eliminate a lot of things just by seeing where the actual pain is and the severity of it in specific spots. My regular pain killer, oxycodone, does very little for the pain.  I was given a presc. NSAID (ibupropen), but that caused my creatine to go up as I only have one kidney so I stopped that and it really didn't help that much.  I understand that surgery is the best treatment - but I'm not sure what that involves yet.  I have an appt. with hand surgeon on Feb. 14. Thanks for being here, Diana
Posts.Title: More fun & games - anyone hear of this? dianaleo LilSchatzie

Posts.Content: dianaleo wrote: I have been have excruciating pain in both of my wrists.  I went to a local rheumatologist who ran blood work and it came back with a very high ANA test for autoimmune disease but nothing else out of whack.  She didn't really come up with a diagnosis or treatment - said I needed to see a hand surgeon.  I just went for a second opinion at Columbia Presbyterian in NYC - top rheum. in the country.  He diagnosed it as Periostitis Hypertrophic Osteothropathy and said it is connected to underlying med. condition such as cancer.  I have found it linked to lung cancer, but not breast.  Neither my local or my oncologist at Johns Hopkins suggested that as a diagnosis.  I will be talking with them soon. That rheumatologist is sending me to a hand surgeon in NYC and we will see where it goes from there.  Of course I thought of a hundred things I should have asked - like does this effect my prognosis, will it spread to other joints, etc., but I was just trying to digest what he was saying at the time. My question is:  has anyone delt with this or even heard of it? Mets to spine, hip, skull, femurs, ribs, sacrum Dx 7/7/2009, ILC, 6cm+, Stage IV, 0/8 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 09:47AM - edited Mar 26, 2011 09:47AM by dianaleo Hang in there, Cathy.  It does get somewhat better and don't be afraid to ask your onc for antidepressants and/or anti anxiety medicine to help you cope.  Many of us are on them and they do take away the panicky feeling.  None of us knows what our individual prognosis is - there are many women that have defied the statistics and I for one intend to be one of them.  There are new drugs in the pipeline and hopefully one will be the magic bullet.  In the mean time, live your life and learn all you can about the disease so you can make good decisions, but try not to obsess   I make big plans and pretend that I will be here for decades.  What's the harm?  We all know how you are feeling right now - we've been there - you will get to a better mental place.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 11:04PM dianaleo wrote: I take 1/2 of a 10mg lexapro which is not very much but seems to do the trick and anti-anxiety med clonazipam when things get too overwhelming.  Your story sounds a lot like mine - mornings are the worst, big house,2 stories with laundry in bsmt, dog, cat, husband who likes to entertain, etc.  One thing that really has helped although I fought it for 43 years is a cleaning lady.  My husband insisted, saying he would rather me save my energy for things I want to do.  She comes every other week and charges $65.  I do the 4 bdrooms myself with the help of my roomba robot (3 of the bdrms are seldom used so I just do those when absolutely necessary).  I try to arrange entertaining around when she comes and then just tidy up a bit.  If bathrms are clean and rugs vacuumed I don't think guests will pay much attention to anything else. One of my outlets is to take my dog to the dog park as I really can't walk her very much any more.  It has been a good social outlet for me also as there are a bunch of us that go during the week when it is quieter and not so many weekend macho men and their dogs.  Actually, in this colder weather the dogs seem to enjoy it more and are more active.  I will go any day when weather is above 26.  I would guess that  the added leg-nerve pain is just enough to send you over the edge on top of all the other crap that goes with this disease.  The pallitive care dr. sounds like a good idea, but definitely an antidepressant is in order.  I take oxycodone for pain and was very afraid I would become an addict. My onc assured me that patients with real pain are not likely to over medicate-so far he is right.  With all my drugs, I just take what I need to get through the day.  So run, don't walk to get the help you need.  I think you'll be glad you did! Hugs, Diana

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2011 06:47PM - edited Sep 6, 2011 06:48PM by dianaleo My TMs are at 195 - they have been going up steadily about 10 pts. every month.  I have had several scans that show everything is the same.  I just went for a PET/CT which my onc does once a year and while it showed no new spots or size increase in known spots, it showed that the two spots I do have are more intense than last year.  My onc says that accounts for the TM rising.  I'm not sure how bad that is.  I see him this week and hopefully will understand it better.  Sloan Kettering and Johns Hopkins do not use PET routinely so when they look at my scans they seem stable.  My two oncs recommend staying on the same treatment for now.  I hope they're right!  If anyone understands what the intensity means in the long run, please let me know.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 11:07AM - edited Jun 23, 2011 11:08AM by dianaleo Definitely, definitely, seeks some help with medication.  If not now, under these circumstance, can you think of a more difficult time when you might need them?  My husband insisted I see a psychiatrist to help me cope.  I am on a low dose antidepressant (sometimes you have to try more than one to get the right drug and dosage) and when need be I take an anti-anxiety med and I am only coping with cancer, not children, finances or other worries.  The meds work very gradually, but eventually you should be able to focus and cope better.  Best wishes. Diana
Posts.Title: How to stay more even .. anxiety meds? JeninMichigan jenn3

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 10:42AM - edited Apr 29, 2011 10:43AM by dianaleo  Antidepressants and anti-anxiety medication are in my aresenal against this disease that is robbing me of everything, including my sanity.  I go to a psychiatrist for these, and my onc felt they were an excellent solution to deal with all of this.  I had reached a point of real despair (it was actually due to hyperparathyroid disease)  and the meds help a lot.  It wasn't really fair to my husband to have to deal with hysteria 24/7.  After surgery for parathyroid, the dr. wanted me to continue with antidepressants (I only take 1/2 of 10mg. Lexapro) and I take the anti-anxiety med only when I am truly anxious (ie, before scans mostly).   My psychiatrist just added Deplin which I understand is a kind of folate that cross the brain/blood barrier.  I think it has helped a lot with my general well being.  At the same time I stopped taking Lipitor so that could also be the reason I feel better.   I feel if there was ever a time to use these drugs it is now.  I'm not the least bit ashamed of telling anyone about them.  I have always been a very strong person, never relying on any crutches to get me through rough times, but with this one I'm smart enough to know when I need help.

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 10:40PM dianaleo wrote: My husband and I have a rather unique situation - we are both cancer patients with not great prognoses.  We live on a roller coaster -I'm up, he's down and vice a versa.  He has kidney cancer so one of us is either going for a scan or waiting for results.  His may be a little more tricky in that there are not many treatments available for kidney cancer.  He had a kidney transplant and developed cancer in the kidney bed of native kidney that was removed. He can understand exactly what I am going through, although we each handle our cancers in our own way - he is able to block it out in large chunks of time and I obsess about it every waking moment.  We go to each others appts. when there is big stuff going on, but when things are stable we each usually go alone. We sometimes hit bottom together and that can be stressful, trying to keep things going around us - cleaning, cooking, shopping, yard work -when we both feel like hell.  Neither of us is doing too badly right now, but I do worry about what is down the road for us.  Yeah, like we're the only ones!

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2011 07:57AM dianaleo wrote: I have lobular cancer.  Even when I had first dx - just had breast exam two days before found it on mammogram and dr. didn't feel it and it was 7+ cm.  I have PET/CT scans, CT scans and bone scans.  The mets do show up, but I am concerned that my TMs are rising and nothing is showing up.  I'm afraid they'll find it in one of those weird places.  Katie11, you're so right - it's scary!
